4723860/4719975/4782809.title: The Holy Family
4723860/4719975/4782809.text:
(continued from previous page)
never rotted in its grave. It is supposed from the time of the Holy Family every donkey has a cross on its back, and there was never any up to that. The old people say that when Our Lord was born the birds sang round the house in the middle of the night.



Once when Brian Boru was in bed tired after warring with the North men, was he was looking up he say a spider making a web. It made five attempts to get from one rafter to another and the sixth time it got across. Brian got up out of
(continues on next page)

4769960/4762916/4925007.title: Brian Boru in Clonbrin
4769960/4762916/4925007.text:
BRIAN BORU IN CLONBRINWhen Brian Boru was fighting in Clonbrin the Dames were one side of the river Slate, and he and his army were the other side. There was a bridge across the river, and a road led up from it to where Brian's camp was in the centre of Mr. Colgan's field.The Danes had a chest of gold and when they saw that Brian's army cuming upon them they threw the chest of gold and any other things they had into the river over the bridge.It is still there and when the river was being cleaned up they found it, and they could not get it up. It lies between our part of the river and Mr. Colgan's. The road is still to be seen across the fields and when Clonbrin was being divided they was the ring where Brian's camp was, and they found bones in boxes when they were making the dich.
(continues on next page)

5055995/4879706/5056073.title: A Story
5055995/4879706/5056073.text:
A STORYBrian Boru left Kincora with his army and came down the Shannon. The first place they arrived was to Scattery Island. They then left the Island and went to Kilrush and remained there for a few days.They then left Kilrush and came up through Cooraclare and there Brian Boru left his army. He then rode on his horse with one of his soldiers towards Cahermurphy as the Danes were camped in the fort and Brian Boru could not get in to the fort as the gates were locked.He rode near a
(continues on next page)
5055995/4879706/5056073.school_info: School: An Chríoch (Cree), Cuar an Chláir

5008902/4965375/5106021.title: Souterrain in Mr Tallon's Field in Fenner
5008902/4965375/5106021.text:
There is a vault in my Father's land at Fennor. It is in the field adjoining Mr. Wall's land near the road leading from Fennor to Michnanstown. The old people about Fennor used to tell stories of a man that lived in Fennor long ago and who opened the vault. That is how my Father got to know about it. One day about two years ago my Father got an old man of the locality to point out the place where the vault was. It was opened, my Father went down into it and there was a bee hive chamber first and a short passage at the end of it. It appeared as if the had fallen in.



R. Dunne Rath says that Brian Boru's funeral on its way from Swords to Duleek passed through Ardcath and down the back road to Micknanstown.

5162111/5155180/5170255.title: Place Names - The Graveyard of the Leinstermen
5162111/5155180/5170255.text: When Brian Boru was encamped in Kincora, the King of Leinster came to visit him. A quarrel arose between the sons of Brian who were playing chess. Murrough said something that insulted him, and he left the place immediately. Brian sent a messenger after him, and he overtook him but the king killed him. Brian and his troops followed over to Portroe to a hill called Lougtea. A great number of the Leinster were slain and were buried there. It is known as The Graveyard of the Leinster men.

4921836/4895566/5183901.title: An Incident of Olden Times in Araglen
4921836/4895566/5183901.text:
In Araglin a place called the "Lios" is covered with furzes, which cannot be burned.Near this spot in years gone by, lived a man, his wife, and their only child.  In these times Irish men had to work as slaves for the Danes:  or the penalty was death.One morning this man on going out to work, told his wife that she must kill their only child and Cook it for their supper, as they had nothing else to eat.  each time she faced the child to kill him, he used to burst out laughing and the mother used to start screaming wildly.  It so happened that Brian Boru in passing that way heard the commotion inside, and on inquiring discovered the tragedy, about to be enacted.  He gave her two loaves ordering her not to kill the child.  When the father returned home that evening, he was glad to know that something
(continues on next page)

metadata.Informant: Mr William Casey, Liam Ó Cathasaigh
